content:
ry 5, 2014
												So, this game brings me back to Gauntlet II. Most. Epic. Game. EVER.First of all let's talk about the classes: every type of character is particular.Rangers: those rangers, man. Their sprite is too awesome, too. I didn't play the game to much but I still like them, their first spell especially, it reminds me of bomberman, an old game for C64.Paladins: the paladin is the tank/support of the group, his engage/disengage (first spell) just helps out ALOT by helping other members to do DPS while he's taking everything. Usually I buy the +health thing from him, helps out alot when you must save the other member's boogie. ♥ They can do alot of DPS with their basic attack, though, so they DO damage.Wizards: the mages. I mean, the mages. The class we fell love with in every RPG/MMORPG. I just love their fireball, so good. I like even the sprite of his robe and his staff/wand.Warlocks: 2muchdmg4y'all. Seriously though, their damage is just INSANE as.. ♥. I mean, their first spell (the lighting bolt) when combined with the Nova "powerup" it's just too awesome.Overall a great game (9/10), recommend to play this with gamepad.

content:
y 3, 2014
												There's a bit of a learning curve to this game, but if you are able to stick with it you'll find a real gem here. First of all, as many others have pointed out it is very similar to the core concept behind Gauntlet. At it's core, it follows the same 'find all of the keys to get to the exit' formula, but this gameplay is augmented by player progression, special abilities, backtracking, and boss fights. It's colorful, lots of great effects, and has a generally high production value.I'd also like to express a few issues I have with the game, but at the same time point out that these should not necessarily deter you from buying/playing the game, just give you a better idea of what to expect.First, there's no steamcloud support. To me this is a basic feature if you're going to put a game on steam.. it'd be forgivable if it were a roguelike with no persistence, but this is a long-play game. Anytime a game doesn't support steamcloud I have to copy the save to my dropbox before I go to work.The decision to make the paladin the 'default' character for players who just start the game without changing options is questionable. The paladin takes a fair bit of skill and nuance to play effectively- not to mention that just about any other game that has a paladin gives that class some sort of healing ability. This paladin has a charge/dash. It's a great skill, but just not what people are going to expect when diving into the game for the first time. Your average player is going to start the game, get swarmed and die repeatedly. Personally I think the wizard probably would have made a better default character.There is virtually NO onboarding in this game whatsoever. The closest you get to a 'tutorial' are these little 'hint boxes' that you have to attack, but if you happen to take a warp or staircase past the first floor (not as hard as it sounds) you'll never see them. An actual onboarding level or optional tutorial would go a long way to making the game more digestible for the average gamer. After my first 30 minutes of playing this game I nearly wrote an angry email to the friend who recommended I buy it, but I persevered and found the diamond in the rough.The soundtrack is nice, but personally it doesn't gel with the art style. I feel like a retro chiptune style soundtrack would have fit better, but that's just my opinion. What's in the game is good, it's not distracting, so in the end it is what it is. I just feel like it's an area where they could have given the game a bit more personality.A lot of the encounters aren't really balanced for single player. It's clear to me that they are pushing for coop multiplayer for this game, but a bit more thought could have been given to making sure the singleplayer experience didn't suffer. It's not bad, mind you- I have a singleplayer game going right now and as an example- I was able to full-clear the first 3 floors without dying once, but during the first boss battle I died 9 times. It's not so much that the fight is hard, it's just that they spawn you right in the middle of an area where you're going to take damage immediately (and a low armor class is going to die quickly). So that's just an example, but you'll see little hints of it throughout the game. Not a huge deal, still very enjoyable as a single player game.So, TLDR version: It's fun, great, awesome. Hard, steep learning curve. Stick with it and you'll love it.

content:
, 2015
												This is like an over world zelda game. If you get this game you will NOT be disappointed. I highly recommend it and think it's absolutely fun and amazing. It offers 4 player multiplayer co-op and the fun can last for hours on end. I recommend having a controller though as tapping the same button over and over for an attack and get repetitive and fast. The only other thing that this game doesn't have is online multiplayer saves. Say you reach a save point in a multiplayer session and it takes 5 hours to reach a certain point. If you save and then turn it off and then turn it back on try to get back to where you were, it won't let you and you'll have to restart from the beginning which is a super downer :(. However despite that, it's super fun and there is no other game like this on steam! It's fun, unique, and it has 6 different classes you can play as now!!! (it used to be 4 but with updates it's 6). There's plenty of content to explore and it offers a challenge every time you play it (unless you use cheats ;P) and not only that but you can even get mods for this game online making it even better offering different modes of play- and yes they all offer online multiplayer as well. Even if this game is full priced I HIGHLY recommend it, but I would say wait as this game does go on sale, and recently I saw it for .83 on indie gala during the spring sale recently and it also can drop down to other prices too like 2.50 so be sure to pick up this game when it's on sale.

												A surprisingly fun title.  While not as deep as other similar dungeon crawlers, the constant barrage of foes to keep running through keeps your attention.  The soundtrack, while quite small, is unexpectedly epic for a game that looks like it came from the 16-bit era.  This is definitely a co-op title, as some of the levels require a variety of classes to make the experience infinitely less frustrating.  One note I will make are the bosses, who can come off as insanely cheap due to the hectic action.  There are plenty of secrets abound, and it lasts quite a while. I can reccommend this at sale price and with friends.

												The music in this game gives me euphoric recall.  My heart races, my mind sharpens: it's like it's 1992 again and I'm 13 years old and beating this game REALLY F*CKING MATTERS. And the simple yet challenging gameplay is lovely stuff. Keeps me coming back. I always wonder what these throwbacks and roguelikes feel like to gamers who were born too late to play video games in the late '80s and early '90s, because so much of the wonder of these games for me is reliving those nascent glory days that set the stage for my life-long fascination with gaming. I thoroughly recommend this game, even when it makes me want to Hulk Smash my computer.

r 14, 2014
												At the moment of writing this I have only played about an hour of Hammerwatch, so feel free to disregard my "review" if that doesn't seem like enough to get a fair taste.I have always disliked the control-style Hammerwatch uses, but it also implements a few nifty commands that actually makes it work rather well. It does takes a bit of getting used to - unless you're familiar with and/or comfortable with this type of controls - but you should quickly get a hang of it. From what I've gathered this is a game about navigating a labyrinthine dungeon of numerous levels, finding secrets and solving simple puzzles, gathering money-loot and buying skill/ability upgrades, last but not least, it's all about killing hordes of beasts and other foul beings.A keyboard-based (or controller, I think, haven't tested) hack&slash for singleplayer or co-op. If you like the abovementioned concepts and don't mind getting lost now and again, then I'd recommend you Hammerwatch.(If my opinion should change I'll come back and edit this - unless I forget to)

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2016
												Hi folks,this is not gonna be an in-depth review of the whole game mechanics, but I'd like to make a few overall comments on the game itself. Let's start with the good:The game is certainly a hommage to games like the good ol' "Gauntlet" Series of the 1980s and the retro-style "pixelated" graphics are done very nicely. The levels are huge, the automap works quite well and there a few classes which have different attributes and skills the user can upgrade and use.The soundtrack is okay (though it can get repetitive when playing through large areas) and the upgrading system including the collectable "vendor coins" is okay, too.Generally, playing the game can be fun at first - even if you only play it in single player as I did. Anyhow, I'd imagine that playing together with a friend would be even more fun. So far, the game looks like a solid arcade action retro title.But now let's move on to the things which are not so nice. Unfortunately, those are quite a few.1) The game is insanely repetitive. The level sprites and textures change, agreed, Some new enemies show up here and there, agreed. But that's about it. You literally fight thousands upon thousands of the same enemies the same way. Attack, back off, repeat until end of level. Repat until boss. Slay boss. Repeat until end of game. *sigh* In the end your tactics hardly even matter - since the enemies' moving patterns are simplistic (and so are your own), you won't come up with something fancy. Finally, you'll find yourself strafing and auto-firing all along (if you play a ranged class that is). Initially, this is fun, but after two or three hours of doing it all over again, you wish for some fresh air in the game play. Sadly, your wishes will not be fulfilled...2) The balance between the different classes is completely off. While playing e.g. with a ranger or priest, you can safely attack from afar in most situations without ever breaking to sweat while slaying thousands of pathetic enemies. If you choose a melee-based class instead which cannot heal automatically (and you are playing in single player), you will find yourself fighting for your very life against almost every single mob of enemies (health items are scarce). 3) The level design and "puzzles" have a certain way of frustrating you. While solving the puzzles is ridiculously easy, navigating around obstacles and traps on the ground is often needlessly cumbersome and unnerving. Oh, and before I forget: Killing off the player for walking into a trap he cannot foresee / anticipate without giving him a chance to react as in the addon ("boulders") is ever so annoying.Even when finishing a level, there is almost never a way of turning off those traps. Why bother, when the level is finished anyway, you might ask! Well, I haven't mentioned the secret rooms and power ups, yet. There are alot of them (which I like) and some secret rooms are very well hidden (which I like, too). Unfortnately, this leads me straight to the next "pain point":4) Even on "normal", the game is hardly easy to beat without constantly looking for each and every power up and without cleverly waiting before you spend your hard-earned money on a shop (the vendor coins give you a cumulative discount). If you do not take the time to look for secret rooms and look really hard, you may have a hard time in the end. Needless to say that looking for secrets after clearing a level while constantly dodging traps sucks a lot. Even that would be okay, but unfortunately upgrading the wrong skills can lead you to a dead end for your character in the final stages or boss fights.5) Having said that, you might wonder why the devs of the game made the questionable choice of not allowing you "back" into earlier played levels of earlier "acts" to collect power ups and secrets. This can be very frustrating, especially if you know you must have missed something and thought you could go back later just to find out after beating a boss that you actually can't.6) Some boss fights are quite hard - which is actually okay. But some boss fights are simply unfair and it is nearly impossible to beat the boss without losing a lot of lives. Especially two bosses of the addon may be unbeatable with certain classes. This is even more frustrating when you try to prepare yourself for the boss fights, but there is not much you can do: You do not have access to earlier levels anymore and there is no way to upgrade your hero any further. Yep, that would be a dead end. Care to start anew and do it all over again? *ugh*7) I won't spoil the game ending for you, but there is something I cannot forgive the devs of this game, no matter how hard I try: It's a question of honor that beating a game should give the player some kind of reward (and not a slap in the face). Suffice it so say that if you do not collect all (or at least very many) of the "planks" in the game you'll get slapped very hard. Oh, right: You're not told this by the game until it is too late (Yes, you are told that you should collect planks but you are not told *how* important they are or what they are for).Oh, right: And even if you do know, you still can't go back to earlier levels - so if you miss a plank (which, of course, you will only know in the end if it is too late), you can do it all over again...Oh, right: This means that you would have to play the game with a walkthrough from the very first level or spend hours of looking for the secrets without ever knowing whether you have really found everything!Oh, right: This sucks the most. After playing 8+ hours and beating the game I realized that there is no way I can beat the game "correctly" wihtout having to start all over again and I simply didn't know until it was too late.I certainly can accept that "better game endings" or special rewards may be reserved for those playing on higher difficulty levels - that alone would be okay. But blaming the player for not finding every well-hidden secret in the game is simply not fair. There are so many other and better ways of designing a game with "collectables" - e.g. take the recent "Batman" series which still allow you to collect all hidden items even after defeating the very last boss and beating the game. You can even find "helper items" which allow you to better locate the secrets. Why not use something similar here as well? *sigh*So, what's it gonna be in the end?The game has potential and there may be some nice mods around. It may be a lot more fun to play with a friend (and easier, too). But all in all, I will never play this game again after beating it once (also not in multi player). There is simply nothing new which would tease me to do it all over again.When having to judge, I'd give this a 5 out of 10 stars at the most. For the pain point 7) I'll subtract another star which leads me to a 4 out of 10.=> All in all, I'd rather recommend a different game of the same genre - but maybe the game will be more to your liking...

content:
er 1, 2013
												Hammerwatch is an extremly fun coop experience. I would not recommend playing it with random people on the intenet, but with three friends this little game really shines at its best. I can't really imagine it being fun played alone though.The combat seems a bit repetetive and simple at first, but the game is really difficult, because of the sheer amount of enemies and everything feels very precise. I never felt bored when slashing through the absurd amount of enemies on the screen. There are some random elements, like randoms crits and stuns, but everything feels really skillbased. Everytime you die you know that it has been your own fault, there are hardly any cheap deaths (outside of the boss fights...).There are some minor flaws in the game though:One being that you have to do portfowarding, which isn't a problem for exerienced players, but may be a problem for some people. Also I could not get a local game to work, but I did not really bother me.Also I didn't enjoy the boss fights all that much, but maybe thats just me, since my friends seem to have enjoyed it. I found them quite cheap honestly.But overall this is a great game with a nice difficulty curve, challenging but not frustrating and it really encourages teamwork.

content:
, 2014
												Well... my personal opinion on this game is right in the "middle" ground. But nevertheless, it was just enough fun to let me recommend it... but the limit was nearly crossed. First, the solo game, "medium" difficulty. Dungeons are really huge, so huge that sometimes I felt bored. The secrets are sometimes really well hidden, namely hints are not strong enough. After a dungeon "cleanup" (namely 100% money harvested and minions killed), I wander into the whole "floor" for forgotten secrets... and they are so vast, I was nearly disgusted. On the same level, there is so many monsters and so much money to harvest... for toooo long. The bosses and middle-bosses are really hard (kind of out of phase with the overall difficulty), and not loosing quite many lives is damn hard (or you need to do it many times and find "the trick" to avoid loosing even a single life).Online multiplayer: the game does not manage IPv4 UPNP for port redirection (at the time of writing), then if you are behind a IPv4 NAT, your will have to perform port (9995) redirection manually on your router in order to be able to host a game. For the few games I was able to join and not be kicked out... no point. Games were messy and short. The "tower defense" map is really a loss of time. I think the right way to do it is to find people on the community forum and organize multiplayer games with them.Maybe that game "grows" on you when you try to perfect it, for hardcore gaming. I may give some other tries in the future, who knows. The game worked with the linux radeon open source driver and has a 64bits native build.As usual, achievements were not unlocked for me. Seems to be a steam bug, or "bugs" on my internet line...

content:
y 19, 2014
												Very good. I have trouble trying to come up with any reason not to get Hammerwatch. It has everything I look for in a game: great level design, fun yet responsive controls, a decent amount of difficulty, pretty visuals, a non-distracting, more inferred than told story and the best coop I've seen in a while. Each of the four classes is fun to play, I found that neither is more suited than the others in every situation, each having its own set of advantages and disadvantages depending on the situation at hand. It's very satisfying to master each class, that enough had me coming back even after beating the game once. The secrets hidden in the world of Hammerwatch are a big part of the game and I found that going after all of them adds a lot to the experience, which can be said about very few games. Playing the coop campaign in this game is the best part of it all. Having two or more players of complementing abilities adds a whole new level of combat strategy with the teamwork that arises. Hammerwatch is one of the rare games that come up once in a while and remind me why I love games.Pros:+ fun in singleplayer+ better with friends+ the music, the visuals+ just about everything elseCons:- might be fixed by now but my Creative sound card had a few issues with the game when I started, I got a bsod and the save got corrupted so I had so start over

content:
3, 2014
												this is definitely a nice little nostalgia-invoking game. if you're a fan of the gauntlet series (especially the old ones), or if you like simpler-designed hack-n-slashers, this game is possibly a good idea to get. here's a quick review of this interesting title:GRAPHICS: although very 'dated', this is part of what makes the game what it is. it's meant to feel like the console dungeon crawlers of old... and it does.STORYLINE: nonexistant, mostly. it's a gameplay-focused game, you aren't supposed to sit there and think about anything other than making it through the game. this isn't meant to be some epic novelesque game or anything...GAMEPLAY: the controls could probably be a bit better in some ways but they give you some really nice control perks that many games don't. you can keep yourself in one place while rotating to face enemies, or you can strafe around and continually face one direction as you do so that you can fire your projectiles or swing your melee weapon at whatever's in the direction you're facing as you either get closer or go in another directions. you get like 4 actual active skills per charactre if iremember right, one of which is your basic (everyone has a different basic attack). there are no items, no inventory, no levels. instead you will be looting the castle as you go, using gold to buy upgrades to stats, and to abilities. it's simple, it's easy to pick up, and it's full of tons of what this type of game was made for: killing enemies en-masse.REPLAYABILITY: well the game may seem rather unremarkable at first... but factor in a level editor, and up to 4 people online or local co-op along with all being able to play on the same system and you have a console/pc hybrid that allows for a lot of interesting replayability. there are also 5-6 classes currently (there were 5 when i got it but that could vary depending on when you read this review... there was originally 4.), each one being very different from the others and adding even more to the replayability. sadly the newest class, thief, has a huge setback and i'm sure most people besides hardcore roguelike fanatics will hate him: the thief. all of his skills not only cost Mana but also cost gold, which is the equivilant of experience in this game... this makes the thief take a million times longer to level, as unless you go through the game spamming regular attacks only, you won't be doing a lot of upgrading/levelling, and you'll remain weak for a longer period of time. this is really my biggest gripe so far besides one or two other things.CONS:-although almost all the character sprites are fairly androgynous (but leaning towards masculine), they all seem to be male as the sound effects determine. this is kind of a setback for me, as i prefer my hack and slashers to at least allow me a choice in gender or to have some characters be girls and others guys. nothing that ruins the game but would have been nice...-although in 'custom' mode, you can change your clothing color to some extent, a lot of it is miniscule on some characters, and you cannot do it in a normal campaign... why not? o.0;-the controls can be a little clunky at times but not really all that bad. you'll still enjoy it if you're an old school dungeon crawler veteran, i'm pretty sure.-the editor isn't the easiest tool in the world to learn, and you may have to find a 'cheat sheet' for what each item is in it, as their titles don't exactly describe what they are very well, and some things don't match up well with each other. i'm still learning the editor, and will give a better review of that when i get it down.-that's about all i can think of for now, will update this review later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Brilliantly done retro Action RPG that is a lot of fun to play with friends. The goal of the game is to get through a number of sprawling dungeons, filled with enemies, loot, obscure secrets and boss fights, with a big emphasis on combat and looting.The gameplay reminds me a lot of Zelda: A Link To The Past in the way you control your character, though instead of fighting one and one enemy, here it is all about fighting stupidly huge hordes of enemies and getting the highest kill combos possible to activate special abilities, while also dodging a large ammount of projectiles, which lend itself really well to this type of gameplay due to it's smooth controlls. However, you do want to play it with friends, as there appears to be little to no difficulty scaling according to the ammount of players, and you are gonna die a lot if you don't have some friends with you to help.Something also worth noting is that despite it's retro look and game style, it avoids going into Rougelike territory and instead opts with premade maps and a extra lives system, which I like myself as I prefer a well designed static map and more tries per game, though if you want your experience to be randomized you might have to look elsewhere for that. However, the game comes bundled with a map editor so you can make your own dungeons to spice things up after beating the official campaign. It's a bit repetitive, but as a pure multiplayer game it's entertaining, challenging without being unfair most of the time and sports a great retro look and feel without having that limit the quality of the gameplay itself. Worth checking out for sure along with some friends.

content:
y 7, 2014
												After reading some of the reviews people had on metacritic, I decided to write a little something here on steam. While this game is both singleplayer and multiplayer, I found it more fun to play it coop then singleplayer.. I have played and seen all the classes. Each ofcourse has his own advantage. The paladin can block arrows, can heal later in the game and hits quite fast, but is bad against stronger or many mage class enemies. The ranger has enough range to kill most spawnpoints without getting near, but has avarage health and mana. The mage has an AOE fireball, but has little health. And finally the warlock has a poison dagger and an AOE shockball (for mana). The downsides of this class is the limited arc of the dagger (compensated by the shockball).The castle is the same every time you go through it, so if you want to have a different map each playthrough you're out of luck. This said, the maps are big. You need a lot of time to clear them and then some more time to find the secrets in this game. These are well hidden and you need a good eye. Also, while there is only one campaing at this time, the game has a leveleditor to make your own maps. Futhermore, the enemies are more of the same all the time. You have ranged, melee and caster enemies, each with certain abilities (faster, poison etc.). One might find this repetitive, but then again this is a hack and slash game; they are always repetative. The coop game I played lasted about 7 hours for me.In general I would give this game an 8 out of 10.

												A great, classic, Gauntlet-like experience. The first adventure is a linear dungeon romp, but the second official adventure is really where this game shines. Decent game with some fun experiences but the overwhelmingly heavy dependancy on other people makes it less enjoyable. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2014
												I first bought this game a few months after it came out and at first I didn't really like it that much... I always said I would give it another try and this is what I did last week with some friends and I gotta say, we all had a wonderfull time. The game has been updated a lot and it is really good now.The gameplay is nice. The controls are tight.  It may look like some kind of numb Hack and Slash like Diablo 3 where all you have to do is hold your mouse button and move, but it's not. The game is really hard and if you don't come up with a good strategy with your co-op partners you will not survive. Any of the 6 classes can come up to be very usefull in a team. Playing different classes over different playthough is the biggest replay value in my opinion. There are different gameplay mods though and they just released a whole new campaign with new maps and new bosses. That being said, the main campaign is not short. I would say it would take at least 5 hours to beat the first time and even more. This is why you need good friends to co-op this game because you might wanna save your state and come back later to finish.The game has epic 16 bit graphics that will bring your child's memory back. Every class you can play are beautifully charming to admire and it's pretty much the same with any mobs, bosses, floors, traps and stuff in the game. There are small details everywhere that makes the look perfect. The music is also awesome.If you are looking for a great dungeon-crawler indie game, this title is for you.

30, 2013
												Simple mechanics and controls. Visually pleasing. 4 different classes with different stats and abilities. Money is spent on upgrading abilities (pre-determined upgrade types.) Not sure about single-player, but co-op is extremely fun and challenging (you'll probably die a lot.) Save system in co-op is a bit odd, though. The areas in the second half in the game start to wear on you (lots of walking around, tons of enemies.) Took over 6 hours to beat with 3 players on first try. Not a whole lot to say as it's a very simply designed game, but it was much better than expected.

content:
ber 25, 2014
												Its not often i write a review, but this deserves one. Hammerwatch is a great throwback to the old gauntlet game. Multiple classes you can play and upgrade over time, and each act provides unique challenges that get progressively harder, and sometimes trolly. activating or disabling traps may help you in some ways, while leaving you at a complete disadvantage in other ways, really making for a diverse play style. overall, this game is frustratingly excellent. its great co-op, but ive been having fun with single player. to me, its far more challenging and i enjoy that!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 22, 2014
												I'm recommending this game solely on the basis of it being fun with friends. It's a decent dungeoncrawler, the challenges and crutches are fun, the fact it has workshop access and occasional updates is great.HOWEVER, and this is a BIG ♥♥♥♥ING HOWEVER, good luck playing it online with people who aren't your close friends. You'll get kicked from 90% of the lobbies and games you join without a word or anyone saying anything edgewise. The most polite way I can put it is that it's like gradeschool physical education all over again. You want teams to pick you. But then they pick you last. Or, they vote you off the schoolyard and you don't get to play at all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 22, 2014
												Hack/Slash @ it's best!First off it is a pixel game, and I never judge a game by it's cover for this soul purpose, Inside the game is epic.Took a few days to learn  how not to die, once you figure that out your golden till the bosses. I would rate this game a 9\10 it is long if you solo play and actually try to get all the secerts in the game.This is a must buy for any old school gamer or even newer gen gamers, I just finished this game and I have about 40 hours in it. The expansion is long considering the the length of the items you have to obtained, the down fall in this expansion is there is only two bosses, that are pretty easy to kill. I was hoping for the expansion to be alot longer and have more bosses, maybe in the next expansion if they create one. The other plus side to the game is player made maps, I have tried out the editor and feels very clunky for a novice user.  The bonus levels are a trip back to the 80's and I won't spoil that for any new comer, THIS GAME IS WORTH THE MONEY!!

content:
26
												About half an hour into this game it dawned on me: I was having more fun than while playing Diablo 3. This game is what I've wanted all dungeon crawlers to be since the day I first played Zelda and Diablo 1: light hearted multiplayer exploration of a massive dungeon filled with traps and secrets. Having a voice service like Razer is a must; countless times my friend have saved me by yelling "The floor!!!" and thus stopped me from walking into yet another spike trap. This game does not hold your hand; several of the secrets require a good eye to notice. And plenty of them have the feeling of a real DnD session. Like the first time you walk into a small secret room and a rune lights up beneath you... I won't spoil the fun. Instead; grab a friend and journey into the depths of Hammerwatch!PRO'S:+ Multiplayer Dungeon Crawler+ Tons and tons of secrets, traps and puzzles+ Varied classes that shines when you play with friends+ Massive waves of enemies+ Massive game maps+ Excellent graphics+ Adjustable difficultyCON'S:- Same map every time- Watch out for the difficulty: the game ends when you're out of lives (unless you set yourself to Unlimited Lives at the beginning of the game)- Map can be hard to navigate since there's no real mini mapI don't want to end on CON's though; to the game makers: thank you for all your work with this game! It was 100% worth the $10,- This is the kind of game I've been looking for forever. Thank you!

content:
1, 2014
												Brilliantly done retro Action RPG that is a lot of fun to play with friends. The goal of the game is to get through a number of sprawling dungeons, filled with enemies, loot, obscure secrets and boss fights, with a big emphasis on combat and looting.The gameplay reminds me a lot of Zelda: A Link To The Past in the way you control your character, though instead of fighting one and one enemy, here it is all about fighting stupidly huge hordes of enemies and getting the highest kill combos possible to activate special abilities, while also dodging a large ammount of projectiles, which lend itself really well to this type of gameplay due to it's smooth controlls. However, you do want to play it with friends, as there appears to be little to no difficulty scaling according to the ammount of players, and you are gonna die a lot if you don't have some friends with you to help.Something also worth noting is that despite it's retro look and game style, it avoids going into Rougelike territory and instead opts with premade maps and a extra lives system, which I like myself as I prefer a well designed static map and more tries per game, though if you want your experience to be randomized you might have to look elsewhere for that. However, the game comes bundled with a map editor so you can make your own dungeons to spice things up after beating the official campaign. It's a bit repetitive, but as a pure multiplayer game it's entertaining, challenging without being unfair most of the time and sports a great retro look and feel without having that limit the quality of the gameplay itself. Worth checking out for sure along with some friends.

												I first bought this game a few months after it came out and at first I didn't really like it that much... I always said I would give it another try and this is what I did last week with some friends and I gotta say, we all had a wonderfull time. The game has been updated a lot and it is really good now.The gameplay is nice. The controls are tight.  It may look like some kind of numb Hack and Slash like Diablo 3 where all you have to do is hold your mouse button and move, but it's not. The game is really hard and if you don't come up with a good strategy with your co-op partners you will not survive. Any of the 6 classes can come up to be very usefull in a team. There are different gameplay mods though and they just released a whole new campaign with new maps and new bosses. That being said, the main campaign is not short. I would say it would take at least 5 hours to beat the first time and even more. This is why you need good friends to co-op this game because you might wanna save your state and come back later to finish.The game has epic 16 bit graphics that will bring your child's memory back. Every class you can play are beautifully charming to admire and it's pretty much the same with any mobs, bosses, floors, traps and stuff in the game. There are small details everywhere that makes the look perfect. The music is also awesome.If you are looking for a great dungeon-crawler indie game, this title is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 6, 2014
												With labyrinth-esque dungeons, deadly traps, and hordes of enemies all skinned with a stylized 16-bit retro flair, Hammerwatch presents near endless hack-and-slash rogue-like action for up to four players to enjoy together. Reminiscent of old classics such as Gauntlet, players are thrown into the bowels of Castle Hammerwatch as one of six playable classes, and must proceed through four Acts of increasing difficulty as they struggle to ascend to the top of the castle and find what treasure awaits them; fighting off seemingly endless enemies and four blood-thirsty bosses as they do.Each class in the game has its own unique traits and abilities along with upgrade paths available for purchase from hidden merchants throughout the various dungeons. Of these classes, the Thief is the one I frequent the most. With high mobility and a wide attack range from his dual wielded daggers, the thief is all about getting in and out dangerous situations while cutting down swathes of enemies with his blisteringly high attack speed. As for skills, the Thief starts out with Fan of Knives, which upon activation throws multiple knives in an arc in front of him, damaging and piercing through multiple enemies. His two other unlockable skills are Grappling Hook and Smoke Bombs, the first of which can be used to hook any nearby wall and then quickly pull you towards it, stunning foes in the process; while the latter acts as a large area of effect (AoE) stun. A unique feature that only applies to the Thief however is that while all his skills cost significantly less mana than the other classes, they also have a secondary cost of gold, which partially balanced by his passive ability to steal gold off the corpses of slain enemies. In addition to the Thief, the other five playable classes available at this moment are the Paladin, squaring off behind his towering shield, the Ranger, which focuses on ranged attacks with his bow and wave clearing bombs, the fireball casting Wizard, the treacherous Warlock, wielding a poisoned dagger and blood magic, and lastly the Priest, who you guessed it, has a knack for healing teammates.A feature that really adds to the depth and replayability of Hammerwatch is it’s accessibility to being modded. This means custom campaigns, custom game types, new enemies, and hell, I’ve even seen prototypes for brand new playable classes on the forums. When the game first came out, it was all about downloading custom files and then manually adding them to the correct file folder the game’s directory for the mod to be installed correctly, but recently this all changed when the game finally got full Steam Workshop support, nearly a year after its initial release. This gives a huge new audience access to the piles of custom campaigns already out there, as well as inspire new modders to create even more content for that larger audience. In addition to its accessibility to installing and using mods, Hammerwatch also comes packaged with its own custom Level Editor/Development Program. With this tool you can do anything from drag and drop existing resources onto your workspace and make your own custom dungeons to even going as far as scripting and uploading your own custom resources. While the level editor program has a ton to it and can be rather intimidating to get into and start working in it, there are multiple Youtube video tutorials on the subject which will walk you through at least the basics.Although at its core, Hammerwatch is a retro hack-n-slash dungeon crawler, the base difficulty and default settings give a very rouge-like feel to the game as well. The players have a set amount of lives shared among them and once you run out, your progress is lost; and on top of that, even on normal difficulty, the game can be incredibly dangerous and difficult, with most traps and some enemies being able to kill you in just a single hit. And even though I happen to find enjoyment in getting dismembered time after time and then drowning in my own pity and incompetence at the game, others who have issues with the initial difficulty of the game can give themselves handicaps such as having infinite lives in the game settings to get rid of these rouge-like elements.With more than 25 hours logged in on it already and more to come once I gather my old group together to tackle some of the new Workshop content, I can say it’s been more than worth the low price point, and even more so if bought on Steam Sale. So if you’re into any game with high difficulty, looking for a game with some great nostalgic vibes, or just an enjoyable easy to get into Co-op game to play with some friends on your day off, then I highly recommend looking at Hammerwatch.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												I still haven't been able to finish this game all the way through, but I have had one hell of a good time so far. Having several classes to choose from makes each runthrough all the more different and having those vendors set up all around the dungeons makes for a seemingly endless number of possibilities of how your run will turn out. Part of me wishes that it was a randomly generated dungeon each time, because I think it would work very well for this game, but it seems to be fine how it is, the dungeons are confusing enough, random generation would make me go insane. And from what I take from the story, you have been separated from your group due to a collapsed bridge and you're forced to traverse the monster dwelling dungeon to reach your goal. Gold, mana crystals, food, keys, and other items will aide you throughout your quest. Fight monsters/bosses, solve puzzles, upgrade your character, you name it! All can be done in the game, Hammerwatch.There are quite a few games nowadays that use pixel-art to stylize their games, but in many occasions, it's not never well done and looks similar to something drawn in MSpaint. HOWEVER this is not one of those games. Whoever made this game should be patted on the back and given a firm handshake for the look of this game. This game is dang beatiful, if I may say so myself. The use of shaders is also very well done. The realistic lighting, bloom/glow effects, dark and colorised lighting makes it just that much better and works well to set the general dark mood of the game.One issue that I have run into is the saving. You save by standing on a checkpoint and it overwrites your previous save to one designated run slot. If you died, you can re-load the save and you'll start back from the last time you reached a checkpoint. BUT, this can be extremely aggrivating if you save at a checkpoint with low health. You'll continue to start back with that same amount of health until you find some food, and if you're in a position where there's basically none, you'll have to die and die and die and die untill eventually you weasel your way through the dungeon on scraps that the enemies drop. Another issue I've found is the difficulty. Bear  in mind I was on the Medium difficulty and you can set it to Easier in-game, I'm just noting my experience. After a few floors have passed you'll find yourself being bombarded with constantly respawning enemies at "nests". They spawn so quickly that it's inevitable that you're going to take a few hits while trying to take it out. This is find for one or two nests, but when there are like 15 in one room, you're basically ♥♥♥♥ed. And I was on Medium, I couldn't imagine doing that on hard mode. Other than those blasted nests, the enemies are pretty fairly balanced, you got slow moving large-healthed monsters, fast moving low-healthed, very slow moving but capable of shooting projectiles. Difficult at first but once you get the hang of it, you'll be fine.Other than these two extremely miniscule issues, this game is perfect. I highly recommend picking it up at full price or on sale.

content:
, 2015
												Friend suggested this to me for a variation on our Co-op playing, and well worth it.  The game's retro art style may be a bit pixelated, but it's clean, crisp, artistic pixels.  Gameplay is solid top down hack and slash and every character class feels different with it's own play styles.There does feel to be some balance issues with the classes, at least in solo play, as some classes are decidedly stronger in different stages of the game, but in a team you can balance that out against each other.  For instance, Ranger's abbility to snipe at a large distance is very useful early on, while Warlock in the early game just has a basic dagger and a spell that, while powerful, recharges slowly.   But by endgame the ranger has to pick it's fights more carefully while the Warlock can use it's third spell and run through multiple monster spawners, regaining HP from hits and mana to recast the spell infinitely.The music is solid, though a bit more variation could be nice, the main Hammerwatch Campaign uses one song for each set of 3 floors within a Act, plus a boss theme, and a Retro theme for the Secret levels.   And since each act can take about 2 hours, you'll hear that same song a long time.   It's good but a variation wouldn't hurt.The main campaign is worth revisiting a time or two, but nothing changes aside from difficulty and which character you use, while there's also Temple of the Sun with some differences to the formula.  But it need not end there, as Workshop lets players create their own maps, so the game should continue on for a while.   Only downside is, there's no way to create custom bosses or characters so unless the game gets a update on those, the challenge will come from floor design.All in all a 8/10 experience, and that's only because I'm late to the party.   With maybe some character tweaks or even additional classes, and bosses, this could be a even better game, and since it's already recieved one major patch, I wouldn't rule anything out at any time.

content:
26
												About half an hour into this game it dawned on me: I was having more fun than while playing Diablo 3. This game is what I've wanted all dungeon crawlers to be since the day I first played Zelda and Diablo 1: light hearted multiplayer exploration of a massive dungeon filled with traps and secrets. Having a voice service like Razer is a must; countless times my friend have saved me by yelling "The floor!!!" and thus stopped me from walking into yet another spike trap. This game does not hold your hand; several of the secrets require a good eye to notice. And plenty of them have the feeling of a real DnD session. Like the first time you walk into a small secret room and a rune lights up beneath you... I won't spoil the fun. Instead; grab a friend and journey into the depths of Hammerwatch!PRO'S:+ Multiplayer Dungeon Crawler+ Tons and tons of secrets, traps and puzzles+ Varied classes that shines when you play with friends+ Massive waves of enemies+ Massive game maps+ Excellent graphics+ Adjustable difficultyCON'S:- Same map every time- Watch out for the difficulty: the game ends when you're out of lives (unless you set yourself to Unlimited Lives at the beginning of the game)- Map can be hard to navigate since there's no real mini mapI don't want to end on CON's though; to the game makers: thank you for all your work with this game! It was 100% worth the $10,- This is the kind of game I've been looking for forever. Thank you!

content:
er 20, 2013
												My friends and I enjoy playing co-op games together and were looking forward to checking out this rpg.  There are only a handful of characters when we played but they all have interesting powers that really ramp up as you level.  The levels are long and really challenging, so you'll want to play with as many friends as possible.  Sadly death comes easy, and you'll have to start at the beginning if everyone falls without making a save along the way.  What's interesting is that you can choose handicaps to make the game less challenging.  But then it feels like you're giving in to the difficulty. so you'll try to use as few as possible.The level selection is rather limited as well, and you can't choose an individual level within a campaign, which we found very debilitating.  Hammerwatch does have a level editor and community content, though we've never found the urge to try them with the amount of professionally done content the game had to offer.  Overall a fun game if you catch it on sale and are looking for something to play with friends.

												Game is pretty awesome and highly addictive.  Gauntlet style dungeon crawler gameplay with an auto attack and single special attack on 4 or 5 classes of champion, as well as different upgrades (effectively a simple levelling system) purchasable from vendors throughout game to boost damage/health/armor/mana/whatever you choose. The game has a simple multihit threshold comboing system that can heal you or deal damage in a circle around you, or both.  Overall an incredibly fun game both single and multiplayer. Definitely check it out if you are into retro style games, it's worth every penny!

												Hey Everyone this is my review about the game!This is a Pixel dungeon crawler game.Interface/Settings/MenuYou are able to play Local co-op.You are able to play online.There are many resolution sizes available.You are able to play fullscreen or windowed mode.There is a master volume slidebar available.There is a sound volume slidebar available.There is a music volume slidebar available.You are able to change the controls on the keyboard.About the game.You are stuck inside of a dungeon. The bridge has collapsed and you are on the other side. This is not a rogue-like game. Enemies can be slain quickly but they are usally packed and swarmed. I think characters with ranging range has an advantage in the game. You are able to find money and food laying around. You do have a set of lives and everytime that you are dying. You will be set back to your last checkpoint. There are keys and secret area's. You are able to find some secret area's at cracked walls. Once you have run out of lives. Its just game over, which could happen fast.You are able to choose your class.There is a manual/instruction about the gameGame could be abit boring and repetitive.Game is okay.Gameplay is slow.Secret Area's.Lives.Shops and other stations.Graphics are okay. Pixelated and from topview.Music is decent.Other Things.None.I give this game a 7/10!

When a game this cheap is this captivating and fun at the same time, I just HAVE to write it a good review. I hope that you guys buy and enjoy this game as much as I do, as well as send the devs some love.

												Three friends and I bought this game, and before we realized what had happened, it was six hours later.This is Gauntlet-style hack'n'slash done right in every way. Just simple, arcade-y action that's as challenging or easy as you want it to be. I can't imagine it'd be particularly compelling solo, but the co-op is fantastic and the classes really are unique and mesh well together (<3 forever my Priest buddy). Workshop integration is a great touch, and the included expansion seems huge! You're not going to find more content for your buck anywhere else. A great investment.

STOP.....!  Hammer(watch) Time!Play if you...* Love the old Gauntlet games and want to play the early 90s sequel that was never made.* Are looking for something to play with friends.* Dig retro-appeal (the game even has screen effects to make it look like an old CRT monitor).* Like smashing through hordes of simplistic enemies.Don't play if you...* Expect deep RPG mechanics.* Want to solo all the content (some characters are not solo friendly).* Hate the retro fad.* Aren't good at action games.BOTTOM LINE: A great take on Gauntlet style action/rpg-lite/puzzle games that does plenty to differentiate itself from being a bland clone.  Play it.

content:
ber 18, 2015
												More fun the more players you have, with smooth and functional online or local coop that allows you to save and continue your game in multiple sessions. With an emphasis on huge hordes of enemies and traps galore, there is plenty of fun to be had exploring and crushing massive swarms of enemies that fill the screen, and a variety of classes to make multiple playthroughs appealing. An assortment of workshop content can enhance your mileage even more. By default, it can be quite challenging, but there are plenty of options to customize your experience and make it easier or harder depending on your tastes. Infinite lives, no lives. Regenerating health, 1 health. The extra options add some spice and make it a good candidate for multiple sessions even after you finish the main campaign. It's all built on top of a game whose core combat feels fast and satisfying, and that's always bombarding you with rewards just as much as it is with enemies. Well, maybe a few more enemies than rewards.

												I highly recommend this game. It is the best RPG on an electronic device that I have ever played. The graphics are good, the classes are mostly very different, and the battle mechanics are very fun (I love cutting through vast hordes of monsters). content:
8, 2014
												I enjoyed Hammerwatch. It's very nostalgic of Gauntlet (one of my favorite games of all time) and even has bonus levels that are made to look exactly like Guantlet. One thing that may turn some people off is it's insane difficulty. They nerfed it in the recent patch but Hammer watch is still a very hard game. The Game is split up into 4 acts, each with 3 floors. On each floor theres a red switch, when you've pressed all three then the door to the boss of that act opens. Each level is filled with secret doors and puzzles that you can find to get extra gold. Theres also alot of game referances in the secrets you find. the gameplay is from a top down view, you kill monsters and collect loot while finding shops to buy upgrades. I would advise playing with a controller but i played with a keyboard aswell and it worked fine.The only thing that is truly annoying is that there's no save while playing multiplayer and it takes about 6 hours to beat the whole game.  Overall its a really fun little game definitely worth 10 bucks and a must have for Guantlet fans.

Lots of secret areas, multiplayer is fun, and overall good game.My only gripes are that you can't use the mouse to aim or anything, they could have done better with that and that you either need to use Hamachi or Port Forwarding in order to get multiplayer working (as a host).

ry 27
												Hammerwatch is a very fun dungeon crawler, best played with friends as a co-op multiplayer game.The game shines in its fun and gameplay. It doesn't really provide any story but this doesn't matter. The gameplay is pretty simple, though the devs still managed to keep it from being boring. There are different classes you can take and every class has its own set of skills. You can buy and upgrade these skills along with other usefull stuff. The stages each have their own secret passages and even easter eggs; the game starts to feel like an old school dungeon crawler.The replayability increases with the modifiers: you can play around with these modifiers to make sessions easier/harder/simply weird. For example: a shared HP pool (in multiplayer), infinite lives, max hp = 1, etc.Best played with a controller and friends.

content:
ry 9
												Hammerwatch is a fun dungeon crawler with two medium sized campaigns. This game is even better with friends and has a lot of extra features which add a lot to the multiplayer experience. There's not a lot of replay ability in the game but the abundance of workshop content; good and bad, makes up for this.-The gameplayThe game, while having two good campaigns, is not a story orientated game. Therefore this review will mainly focus on the gameplay aspects of the game. The art style of this game very much reminds me of the original Gauntlet. Top down, pixel graphics. The game has RPG aspect, wherein you have a pick from 5 characters; Paladin, Mage, Thief, Warlock and Priest. Additionally throughout the game there are vendors and NPC where you can upgrade your skills or stats and buy new ones. The combat in the game is simple, you can amass 4 attacks/skills. As you increase your level the base level of the new attack/skill is higher. The combat can get very repetitive and it does come down to button mashing on occasion to clear out the hoards of enemies in front of you.-The ExtrasThe game has a number of different settings you can apply to a playthrough. Such as shared HP pool, infinite live (default is 1 life for each player; where respawn bases can revive dead players) and much more. The extras provide a new type of playthrough to the original campaigns. However this extra alone do not provide a great deal of replayability and that is where the plethora of workshop content comes into play. -The workshopDue to the short nature of this game's short campaigns, yet addicting gameplay (to me atleast). The amount of community made content on the workshop is enough to keep you satisfied, but not too much so you don't know what to get. Some of the campaigns have an incredible amount of detail, making it hard to distinguish some of them from the original campaigns. Personally I would recommend Ravenwatch It's a dark well made adventure; and I shall say no more.All in all if you can get past the eventual repetitive nature of the combat the concept is great and the addition of the workshop content makes for a good throwback to gaming in the early years.

												Just a really fantastic game. I've finished the main campaign and the new Temple of the Sun campaign on regular difficulty and have 55 hours total. Plus a bunch of tries to get Survival mode down. The different characters really all do play quite different, have beat it with the ranger and the priest. The few downsides is that the game tries to beat you mostly with numbers of enemies rather than very intelligent ones, but still remains quite challenging especially on hard (and survival mode is BRUTAL). The other thing is that there is no actual reward for killing enemies, they are mostly just obstacles for you to explore for loot and secrets. That said, I loved this game in single player and it's even miles more fun as multiplayer. Hope they get another new campaign in the next patch. Add me if you want to play!! stewnwt

												I have played multi-player for about 3 hours with my brother and I played solo thru the first dungeon defeating the first boss. I have tried all the classes for at least 10-15 minutes. So far, it's been a really fun game. If it's on sale, no brainer, buy it. It'll be worth your money and time. If it's not on sale, buy it if you like the original Gauntlet or  any twin-stick shooter (for the record, it is NOT twin stick, but it's very similar). I will say this: have a good graphics card. The system requirements say Open GL 1.4 minimum, but I could NOT get it to work on my laptop which meets the recommended requirements except for the Open GL 2.0. I would say minimum requirement is 2.0. Further, the graphics are really good if you do have the graphics card to support it.Last note for this game and honestly for Steam and PC gaming in general if you like retro games... buy a game pad. This game absolutely requires it. I played on KB and controller. And the difference is huge. Thank you and I hope this review helped you decide to buy it or not.

content:
er 14, 2014
												Someone made an exceptionally ugly and un-fun action RPG. How original. I understand I'm in the minority if you look at the Steam ratings. I just don't agree with them.Hammerwatch is a fairly basic, straightforward action RPG. It's a dungeon crawl that compensates for the few enemy types with an overabundance of them. It's the same game that I've played and seen dozens of times. There are no new mechanics to speak of here. It's spam the attack button and clear out enemies. Rinse and Repeat. Careful positioning of your character and taking care to min/max your build is what's needed.Here's the problem. That sounds like every other action RPG game in the last 20 years. In this case the devs decided that since they didn't have any graphical skills, they should just create ugly pixel blobs for everything and try to pass it off as "retro". I saw better looking games on my Atari 2600. I'm not kidding either. I'm all for a unique and interesting art style. It doesn't have to have modern graphics. But I find these muddled and frankly dull. With the same kind of gameplay I've experienced a dozen times before, I'm not finding any joy in Mudville. Why would I want to play this over any dozens of other games that do the same thing, look better and play better? Maybe there's some cool novel mechanic or awesome story later on (though by all indications there isn't), but if there is I can't be bothered trying to find it given the derivative gameplay and horrendous graphics. I get the sense when I play this I should just go play a similar game that does it better and looks better.I hate to hammer on the graphics so much but when they're this off-putting, it's a massive issue. The meal may taste OK but if it looks like a plate of dog doo your dinner guests won't want to eat it. That's how Hammerwatch makes me feel. Then when I play it and get the feeling that I've done all this before there's no incentive to go on.Again, I recognize that I'm in the minority here but I'm not giving bonus points for ugly, derivative games just because they're indie.

content:
2014
-Quick Review-Hammerwatch is a Dungeon crawler that takes you through 4 levels or “acts”. There are several different classes you can play as. The game feels like a throwback from older 8bit video games, while enjoyable to play occasionally, to try to power through the game was a bit excessive for my tastes (the game play was very repetitive).-Detailed breakdown review-Story: There isn’t much of a story, you start the game out separated from your companions because “the bridge is out!” Because you simply couldn’t jump across that stupid bridge you had to wander throughout the four acts for several hours until you get to the last boss. (and at that point, I really hope you got all the planks, or else you’ll need to do it… AGAIN!) Game Play: Hammerwatch requires excessive spamming of my forward key (it would work better with a controller, or maybe rebinding the attack keys from the keyboard default). I understand that it’s my own fault for not taking the care to get a controller or rebind the key. But I preferred the default set up. I really got tired of spamming my forward arrow, while kiting around and holding down the space bar to strafe.After my 10th hour, it stopped being amusing and fun. I only played as the Ranger class; those of you who know me know I like to play Range classes in video games. In Hammerwatch the ranger seems to be rather over powered as well. There are several other classes that are really fun to try out though.Many dungeon crawlers the dungeon changes shape as you play, or they’re so big you cannot remember where anything else. I found myself getting very bored wandering around trying to get every single thing inside the dungeon. Worse yet; when you play the story mode a second time the dungeon doesn’t change at all. That made “exploring” pretty impossible for me, and finding secret area’s I had missed my first time playing only gives me so much of a thrill. Simply put: I felt like I was grinding, not playing a game.Achievements: The achievements are pretty straightforward. I earned all of them aside from two: don’t plan to get the last two “Slay the Lich achievements” until I have help, or I’m really, really bored with time to burn.The achievements are three categories: 1) Beat the game/boss on _____ Difficulty. 2) Find the secret area. 3) Grind the ____ Amount of NPC’s/Gold. There are good guides in the steam community that assist with the secret areas, which for me was the most work. I had to redo the story mode part of the game Three times.Price: Hammerwatch’s standard price is $9.99, I really didn’t enjoy playing this game solo that much. I’m sure it’s more fun with friends. I guess $9.99 is a fair price, but I think you can get a better game with more enjoyment out of it for that price. I would skip this game unless you really want to try out new games. My recommendation is to wait for a steam sale before you purchase the game. Conclusion: Pro’s: The game was a fresh idea, it was fun to play through once and leave it alone. It was very easy on my graphic’s, I could play it on my laptop (most people could probably play it on their phone).Con’s: The game is very grindy in nature, I was quite tired of spamming my forward key to do attacks, I had to repeat the same story at least three times with no real dynamic differences between the dungeons or NPC’s I fought.I’m not sure if I should be giving this game a recommended or not recommended. I wouldn’t be telling the truth to say I was unsatisfied with the game. I don’t think that most people will get as much entertainment out of the game as I did, and like I’ve clearly outlined I felt like I was grinding most of my time. I would like to say I’m uncertain which way I lean.

content:
3, 2016
												If Diablo had been designed for the SNES then it might look something like Hammerwatch: grind your way through hordes of identical mooks, collecting gold to purchase upgrades.It's an even less interesting Skinner box than Diablo, however, with negligible enemy variety and an utterly tedious upgrade system. There is minimal skill development and no fancy equipment to find. There is no XP so no reward for killing enemies per se; they're just obstacles between you and the gold, of which you need to collect thousands upon thousands of pieces to purchase small and usually uninteresting upgrades.This just contributes to the tedium of murdering identical hordes of hundreds upon hundreds of easily-killed enemies: no reward other than a few gold and advancement to the next room filled with the same opponents. (Later enemies do at least use new sprites rather than just pallette swaps, but the behaviour of bugs and eyeballs and skeletons is nevertheless the same.)The only really notable feature is the combo system, which, when unlocked, gives you a temporary boost after killing 10 enemies in quick succession.I kept playing at first because I thought it was just starting off dull -- as most games with level-up mechanisms do -- and then because I was too far along to give up. I regret the time wasted. It doesn't get better.

er 30, 2014
												The controls, graphics, animation, and general quality are really solid, but the content is spread far too thin and the game consists of mostly doing the same things over and over.  Occassionally you'll see old things mixed together in new ways - an enemy spawner next to a difficult stationary enemy, for example - but then that combination will get re-used dozens of times before you run into anything new, and that new thing may very well be a slightly faster version of an old enemy with different graphics. Tough enemies can take a minute to kill even if you're taking no damage and they pose no threat to you, making them more chore than threat, which only adds to the sense of tedium.The difficulty is also extremely inconsistent.  Some enemies plink away with 1 damage and easily avoided attacks, while more difficult to avoid attacks often take half your life bar or more.  The game's first boss was vastly more difficult than the second.I would have been happy to play this same game with levels a tenth as long and a constant stream of new situations, instead of its current form, which feels like mostly padding.

content:
y 7, 2014
												It just doesn't feel fun to play with the control scheme it has.This game does not let you aim independently from your movement like a normal dual stick or WASD+mouse or WASD+arrows shooter. There are strafe and stand modifier buttons that allow you to lock the direction of either movement or aiming while held down, and that is the only way to do one without doing the other. Furthermore, controllers are more capable than the keyboard setup because the game allows you to disable 8-way aiming on the thumbstick; and since there is no mouse aiming, this is impossible on a keyboard because you are only allowed 8 directions over 4 keys. Same goes for movement, though every game is like that.I'm sure people are thinking, "Dude, you're just not good enough." Well, I seem to be surviving just fine, so that's not it. "It was intentionally designed like that as a throwback to games like Gauntlet." The games it's throwing back to were from a period where design philosophy wasn't as refined as it is now. It's especially hard to understand such design choices since these problems have been solved for quite some time. I'm going to continue trying to beat the campaign with my friend just so we can feel like we got our money's worth. Maybe I'll have come around on it by then.

content:
y 3, 2014
												I'm going to summarize the two main disadvantages to this game (note that these only apply to single player, and I have no knowledge of multiplayer at all):1. The map is terrible.In this game, each dungeon can last literally hours. That may not be too terrible in itself, except it takes even longer because the map screen does not allow you to see the whole dungeon that you've explored at once. The map only shows the areas nearby which you have already seen, and thus is severely limited in its usefulness. This can make exploring the full dungeon a nightmare. It can become a chore trying to find where to go next, sending you running in circles, simply because your map has practically no range beyond you.2. The saving system and game over system are completely horrendous pieces of garbage.You can have several save files, only one per character you start. The game works like this: you have several lives for your character, and if you lose them all, you completely game over and have to revert to your last save or revert to the very beginning of the game. That is complete rubbish. The saving works in that you have one save per character, as said before. You can't revert to old saves of that character. Any time you step on a checkpoint or go to another floor, your game is automatically saved. This hurts you, as if you find you have only one life left and critical health, this game becomes a joke between running to enemies and back to a save point, hoping to God you don't get hit even once. In my personal experience, I went into the first dungeon's boss room during single player. As a reminder, whenever you travel to another floor of a dungeon, your game automatically saves. However, this time, without any warning, the door in which I entered became locked, meaning that I was literally save-locked into the boss room. In a GOOD game, if you found the boss to be too advanced for you, you'd be given the opportunity to backtrack and get more upgrades so that you stand a chance against the boss later. However, in THIS game, since I die in literally two hits to the boss and I can't do anything about it, I have to restart an entire 2+ hours of gameplay, making sure I clear out even more of the dungeon than I did the first time. I'm sorry, game developers, but would it really kill you to take it more like a Legend of Zelda game? In LoZ, if you game over, you get sent back to the beginning of the CURRENT dungeon and all of the enemies are respawned, but you don't lose any upgrades, items, or progress throughout the dungeon. This is still a punishment for losing, but it doesn't make you redo literally hours of gameplay. Even the original Legend of Zelda on the now-archaic NES had this methodology, as Nintendo knew their audience wouldn't want to restart every detail of a long and difficult dungeon. You crazy guys instead, for the far worse, force someone to restart literally the whole game over in the case where they get save-locked into a fight they can't win. This is the kind of design people joke about from the NES era, and it seems you did not pick that hint up. Game-overing someone to the title screen is a joke. Stop using it. It's an easy way to kill a game.Oh yeah, and remember that I haven't even tried multiplayer yet, and I've heard some terrible things about multiplayer. Since I have no experience of it, though, I'll give it the benefit of the doubt (or at least exclude it from this review).It's a huge disappointment, as this game actually would be tremendous amounts of fun otherwise. The characters are unique, the fighting style is linear and remarkable, and the dungeons can hold many great secrets. I swear that if you simply made a better map to allow someone to see more of the dungeon at once, a better save system to allow people to revert to older saves on a character, and a better game over system that doesn't literally force you to do the entire game over again, this could easily become several times more enjoyable and popular.Those things above shouldn't even take that much work to fix. If done with actual care, a developer wouldn't even have to edit any campaign levels.Until the above are fixed for better enjoyability, I highly recommend that you, reader, STAY AWAY from this game. You'll find yourself addicted for a few good hours, then curse its name for such a crappy game over and save system. This game is not too old yet, so maybe the developers will take some heart and at least try to salvage it.In short:This game has tremendous potential, but it is horribly ruined by a bad saving and game over system, along with a map that doesn't help you get un-lost. Generally avoid unless you don't mind replaying literally hours over.

y 18, 2014
												I was expecting a challenging retro-esque roguelike game and what I got was one of the most bland and repetitive games I've played. I played through the whole game with friends, and that didn't enhance the fun one bit. A few minutes into the game I realized the soundtrack (at least in the first area) is just some generic and uninteresting chiptune music played on loop that added nothing to the mood of the game, so I muted it. So then I went on my adventure where I spammed the A button on my controller, occasionally the B button, sometimes the X button, and sometimes Y I guess while facing or being in near-proximity to very boring monster types. I'd also like to mention I played through this game while high, you'd think that would make it more enjoyable but no, it doesn't.Oh, and if youre expecting a challenge: don't. This game was stupid easy, at least on the normal difficulty. I can assume that the higher difficulties are nothing intuitive and are just enemies with more health/damage/speed or whatever, basically making the grind to finish this piece of ♥♥♥♥ game significantly longer and more frustrating than difficult. You are hardly punished for dying. You go back to a checkpoint and lose a life, wow, sounds punishing and roguelike right? Yea. Maybe if you couldnt buy lives, they're really cheap too. On the final boss I literally just bought us around 30 lives giving us around 45 and I just ran at the boss and spammed my lame wizard ♥♥♥♥ at some dragon balls or whatever, died, respawned, and did the exact same thing until the boss died, and I was doing most of the damage.Expect to run around boring environments trying to find boring keys while fighting boring enemies all while literally destroying every wooden box and barrel around you for money that you use to buy boring upgrades, ultimately leading you to an underwhelming duke out with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dragon that can easily be beaten by taking advantage of this games poor mechanics. This game literally has nothing interesting about it other than a level editor.If you feel like sitting on your ♥♥♥ mashing A while listening to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ chiptune music, then whatever that's your thing. If your someone who expects to get your moneys worth of something, or someone who likes video games that aren't ♥♥♥♥, than this game is not for you. ♥♥♥♥ this piece of ♥♥♥♥.

Product received for free
												This game is a great game to play with friends. with every floor almost killing you as you carry your priest to heal you and be your backline you will feel like you are really in the dungeon. The workshop is also a major part of playing this game. If your getting bored of playing the story then you can just download some maps put together by other players or you can just make your own map and have your friends play it. This game has a bit of everything for everyone. like if you want to be on the front lines palidan is great for you. If you just want to lay low and make sure your friends dont use all your anks and die you can play the priest. If you wand to be near the palidan you can play a wizard with lowish health you can spray down clumps of enemies with your flamethrower. Or if you want to be back lines you can play archer and snipe out your enemies from far away and if you find youself facing a crowd of enemies you can drop down your bombs and watch as your combo kills go through the roof. I havent played the other classes so I dont know to much of wat to write for them but they all all well balanced and put together. I think this is the closest game to "the perfect game". If you like rouge like games like binding of Isaac you will love this game.

content:
y 25, 2015
												A good old fashioned dungeon crawler featuring: drop in drop out co op, several unique characters, and most amazingly NO CUTSCENES.I was pleasantly surprised when I booted up the game as I scrolled through the options, there are resolutions from 600x800 all the way up to 4K. What more would you want? maybe a few post processing options to make the game appear as if it is being played on an old CRT monitor? the nerd in me exploded at the sight.It features a campaign that is designed to last around two to three hours, but could be done quicker with serious practice. There is also a lot of strategy when it comes to which class you have picked specifically, such as when you are a priest in co-op ideally you should stick to your teammates; without them your combat skills are very limited. So you tailor your upgrades to support (levelling up healing, increasing movement etc.) and this really helps the characters actually progress. But as these reset every time you start a new game it still keeps the game fresh and allows new strategies to be tested out. I love playing Hammerwatch and recommend it to anyone who wants to have some fun with friends also.5 Stars! Colours, Soundtrack is spot on, and controls feel great.
